Ronald Aspinall (26 October 1918 – 16 August 1999) was an English cricketer who represented Yorkshire and later worked as a first-class umpire. He was born in Almondbury, near Huddersfield in West Yorkshire, and developed a reputation as a dependable lower-order batsman and a right-arm fast-medium bowler.

Aspinall’s first-class opportunities arrived relatively late. He was 27 when he debuted for Yorkshire in 1946, in the period immediately after the Second World War when county sides were rebuilding their squads. Despite a short top-level career, he produced several performances that drew attention. One standout match came in 1947 against Northamptonshire, where he dominated with the ball across both innings and played a central role in a decisive Yorkshire win.

By 1948 he was appearing more often, taking on responsibilities at the head of the attack and sharing the new ball with fellow Yorkshire bowlers. He also featured in the celebrated match against the touring Australian side of 1948, commonly associated with Don Bradman’s unbeaten team. In that fixture, Aspinall managed the notable achievement of dismissing Bradman in the second innings, along with other key Australian players.

His final season at the highest level began impressively. In early 1949 he recorded excellent bowling figures and briefly led England’s national bowling averages, taking wickets at a very low cost. However, a serious Achilles tendon injury brought his first-class playing days to an abrupt end.

After leaving county cricket, Aspinall continued in the game through Minor Counties cricket with Durham during the 1950s. From 1960 to 1981 he served as a first-class umpire, extending his involvement in professional cricket for more than two decades. He died in Almondbury in 1999 at the age of 80.

Romano’s Macaroni Grill is a casual dining restaurant brand known for Italian-American dishes served in a sit-down setting. The chain operates dozens of locations across the United States and maintains corporate offices in Denver, Colorado. Its concept blends familiar American restaurant service with menu items inspired by Italian and broader Mediterranean cooking traditions.

The first Romano’s Macaroni Grill opened in 1988 in Leon Springs, Texas, an area that is now part of San Antonio. The restaurant was created by Philip J. Romano, a restaurateur whose name became closely associated with the brand’s identity. Over time, the original site changed hands and later ceased operations after a fire in 2021, leaving its future uncertain.

The company’s ownership history includes several major transactions. In 1989, Brinker International acquired franchise rights and expanded the concept significantly. By the mid-2000s, Brinker began evaluating strategic alternatives for its large portfolio of company-run restaurants. In 2008, a controlling share of the chain was purchased by Mac Acquisition LLC, tied to Golden Gate Capital, while Brinker retained a smaller minority stake for a period afterward. Another change occurred in 2013, when Ignite Restaurant Group bought the brand in an all-cash deal. Two years later, ownership shifted again when Redrock Partners acquired the business at a much lower reported price, reflecting the challenges many mid-market restaurant chains face as consumer preferences and competition evolve. In 2017, Romano’s Macaroni Grill entered Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, a process often used by restaurant companies to restructure leases and debt while continuing to operate. In 2018, the company expanded its portfolio by purchasing Sullivan’s Steakhouse.

Macaroni Grill’s menu centers on pasta, sauces, and classic Italian-American combinations. A signature offering is a build-your-own pasta option, allowing diners to select noodles, sauce styles, and add-ons such as proteins or vegetables. Meals commonly include complimentary bread served with olive oil, aligning with familiar Italian restaurant customs in the U.S. The brand has also promoted ingredient sourcing from Italy, highlighting relationships with family-run suppliers to emphasize authenticity and traceability.

Beyond dine-in service, Macaroni Grill has extended its presence into retail through packaged food products modeled on restaurant dishes. These items have been produced through a partnership with a large consumer food manufacturer, making the brand available to customers outside its restaurant locations.

Nutrition has been a recurring topic in the chain’s public profile. In the late 2000s, media coverage criticized the high calorie counts typical of many full-service restaurant meals. Later reporting noted improvements, pointing to menu revisions and leadership initiatives aimed at reducing calories in certain entrées and presenting lighter options.

text:
Dark Days is the first full-length studio release by the American rock project Loaded. The album was put together in Seattle, Washington, during sessions that ran from late 2000 into early 2001 at Jupiter Studios. After the recording was completed, it initially appeared as an independent release in mid-2001, reaching listeners in the United States and Japan first. A wider European release followed the next year, helping the record find an audience beyond its original market.

The album’s background is closely connected to earlier songwriting efforts by frontman Duff McKagan. As the sessions took shape, he revisited several pieces that had been associated with his previous work and reworked them alongside newly written material. For the studio lineup, McKagan assembled musicians drawn from Seattle’s broader rock scene. Drummer Geoff Reading joined the project after playing in bands such as Green Apple Quick Step and New American Shame, while guitarist Dave Dederer came in with experience from The Presidents of the United States of America. Producer Martin Feveyear played a central role in shaping the sound and also contributed keyboard parts, giving certain tracks added texture beyond the core guitar-bass-drum setup.

McKagan handled bass throughout the record and also contributed additional instruments where needed. One notable detail is that he played piano on the song “Misery,” showing a willingness to broaden the album’s palette. Guitarist Mike Squires, known for work with groups including Harvey Danger and The Nevada Bachelors, was invited to add extra guitar layers, reinforcing the album’s dense, riff-driven approach.

Before release, McKagan confirmed the title Dark Days and chose to present the material under the band name Loaded rather than as a solo effort, signaling a more collaborative identity. Promotion for the album included a short run of club shows, including dates at House of Blues venues in several U.S. cities. As touring plans expanded, the lineup was adjusted to support live performances, adding players so McKagan could shift between roles onstage. Tours in the United States, Japan, and later Europe helped maintain momentum into 2002.

Years later, the album was reissued in 2008 on both CD and digital formats, with certain editions including bonus live recordings from the band’s Japan tour, offering a snapshot of how the songs evolved in concert.

Berseba is an electoral constituency located in Namibia’s ǁKaras Region, with the village of Berseba serving as its administrative centre. The area includes notable natural and populated sites, such as the Brukkaros crater and small settlements including Snyfontein, Helmeringhausen, Tses, Bethanie, and Goageb. At one point the constituency recorded about 6,659 registered voters. Census figures show steady growth over time: the population rose from 9,064 in 2001 to 10,589 in 2011.

The constituency is also linked to early resource exploration in Namibia. Diamonds were first identified in this broader area in 1898, and petroleum discoveries followed in 1929, highlighting the region’s long-standing connection to mining and prospecting activity.

Political representation has changed over successive regional elections. In 2010, SWAPO candidate Dawid Boois won the council seat with 1,225 votes, ahead of several opponents from parties such as the RDP, DTA, DP, and COD. He retained the position in 2015 after increasing his vote total to 1,774. In 2020, the seat shifted to the Landless People’s Movement when Jeremias Gooieman secured 1,822 votes, while SWAPO’s Steve Sensus Ovambo finished second with 1,127.

Parker Memorial Night is a live jazz release credited to Chicago-based multi-instrumentalist Ira Sullivan, documenting a concert performance from the early 1960s. The session was taped at a benefit-style tribute honoring alto saxophonist Charlie Parker, a central figure in the development of bebop. The recording first appeared on the Vee-Jay label as a single LP, capturing a compact set built around Parker-associated repertoire and a few well-known standards. Decades later, the album was expanded and reissued on CD, adding previously unissued selections from the same event and turning the original program into a longer snapshot of the band’s book.

Critical discussion of the reissue has often highlighted the value of the expanded track list. Reviewers note that the additional performances broaden the view of the ensemble, moving from fast bebop heads to mid-tempo blues and ballad material. The core appeal is the spontaneity of the live setting: extended solos, audible interaction between horns and rhythm section, and the way familiar themes are reshaped through improvisation.

The repertoire centers on Charlie Parker compositions, alongside tunes by writers closely connected to modern jazz and the American songbook. The expanded edition also includes pieces associated with Dizzy Gillespie and other contemporaries, reflecting the wider bebop ecosystem rather than a narrow “greatest hits” approach.

Sullivan is featured primarily on trumpet and flugelhorn, supported by a quintet with tenor saxophone, piano, bass, and drums. The personnel underscores a typical bebop frontline and rhythm section, emphasizing tight unison themes, brisk tempos, and a harmonic language rooted in rapid chord changes and melodic variation.

text:
In the early decades of motorized transport, lawmakers in several places adopted so-called “red flag” requirements for road vehicles. These rules were designed to reduce collisions and prevent horses and pedestrians from being startled by unfamiliar machines. At a time when roads were shared by walkers, carts, and livestock, even a slow-moving automobile or steam carriage could create panic, and governments treated it as a public safety issue that needed special regulation.

In Britain, a series of statutes known as the Locomotive Acts placed strict limits on the use of mechanically powered vehicles on public roads. The best-known measure, passed in the mid-1860s, required a small crew rather than a single driver and demanded that one person walk ahead of the vehicle to provide advance warning. That escort was expected to signal to other road users and to help manage encounters with horse-drawn traffic. The distance between the walker and the vehicle was set far enough to give riders and drivers time to react, and the warning could be given with a clearly visible flag by day or a lamp in low light. These restrictions reflected widespread concern that heavy, noisy machines would endanger the public and disrupt everyday travel.

A similar approach briefly appeared in the United States. In the 1890s, Vermont adopted a law aimed at steam-powered road vehicles, requiring a person to proceed ahead of the machine and alert those traveling with animals. Night travel brought an additional expectation: a red light or other clear signal to increase visibility. The rules generally focused on road-going vehicles and did not cover railways, which already operated under separate safety systems and dedicated rights-of-way.

Red flag provisions did not last long in most places. As engines improved and vehicles became more reliable and controllable, governments shifted toward other forms of regulation, such as speed limits, licensing, standardized lighting, and traffic enforcement. The brief era of red flag laws illustrates a transitional period in transport history, when societies were adapting legal frameworks to technologies that were rapidly changing how roads were used.

text:
“The Novocaine Mutiny” is a fourth-season episode of the television comedy-drama *M*A*S*H*, first broadcast in early 1976. The story is framed around a formal military inquiry, using the structure of a hearing to revisit a chaotic day in the 4077th’s operating room. Rather than unfolding in a straightforward timeline, the episode relies on testimony from different characters, allowing the audience to compare competing versions of the same event and to see how personal agendas can shape “official” narratives.

The plot centers on Captain Hawkeye Pierce, who is accused of mutiny by Major Frank Burns. The accusation is serious: under military law, mutiny can carry extreme penalties, and the threat of a court-martial hangs over Hawkeye from the outset. To decide whether the case merits a full trial, a preliminary proceeding is convened, presided over by a superior officer brought in to evaluate the evidence.

Much of the background to the charge stems from a brief period when Colonel Potter is away from camp. In his absence, Burns takes on acting command and attempts to impose strict discipline. His efforts are less about operational necessity than about control, and they disrupt the unit’s usual routines. One example is a campaign against gambling, which Burns treats as a major breach of order. When a large sum of money goes missing, he launches a broad and intrusive search across the camp, refusing to accept the more mundane explanation that the money was simply lost during a card game. The investigation becomes increasingly petty and personal, creating tension among staff who are already stretched thin by the demands of the war.

During the hearing, witnesses describe the lead-up to the operating-room confrontation. Their accounts emphasize the pressures of mass casualties, limited time, and the need for careful triage and preparation before surgery. Hawkeye’s defense rests on a professional argument: he believes Burns was pushing patients into surgery without adequate pre-operative assessment, increasing the risk of preventable deaths. Burns, by contrast, portrays himself as the only one trying to keep the unit functioning under impossible conditions, casting Hawkeye as insubordinate and reckless.

The central incident is presented in sharply different ways. Burns claims he was deliberately incapacitated so that Hawkeye could seize control. Hawkeye describes a more mundane sequence in which Burns is removed from the operating room after his decisions endanger patients, and an accidental injury contributes to Burns being knocked out. The hearing officer ultimately concludes that the evidence does not justify escalating the matter to a court-martial, treating Burns’s account with skepticism.

After the proceedings, life at the 4077th returns to its familiar rhythm. The episode closes by highlighting the gap between rigid rule-making and the informal culture that keeps the unit functioning, suggesting that survival in a field hospital often depends as much on practicality and trust as on strict adherence to authority.

Antoine Wehenkel (10 February 1910 – 27 February 1992) was a Luxembourg politician with a professional background in engineering. He played a prominent role in the Luxembourg Socialist Workers’ Party (LSAP), serving as its president from 1970 to 1974. His parliamentary career began in 1951, when he entered the Chamber of Deputies, where he remained a central figure in national politics for more than two decades.

During the 1960s, Wehenkel moved from legislative work into government. In the cabinet led by Pierre Werner, he held responsibility for public finances as Minister for the Budget. He also took charge of economic policy in a period when Luxembourg was modernizing its industrial base and expanding energy planning, including in a ministry that combined national economy and energy matters. After a change in coalition in 1969 pushed the LSAP out of government, Wehenkel returned to parliamentary leadership rather than executive office.

He later became President of the Chamber of Deputies, a position that involves overseeing debates, maintaining procedural order, and representing the legislature externally. He held this post until 1974, when he left national politics. Alongside his national roles, he also served on the municipal council of Luxembourg City from 1951 to 1964.

text:
“Never Again” is a phrase best known as a moral commitment to prevent the return of genocide and mass persecution. It is closely linked to remembrance of the Holocaust, but it has also been adopted in discussions of other atrocities and human rights crises. Over time, the words have moved beyond their historical origins and become a widely used title and theme across many kinds of media and public life.

In film and television, “Never Again” appears as the name of multiple productions from different eras. Early cinema includes silent-era shorts and features that used the title for stories unrelated to modern political meanings. Later works include an independent film released in the early 2000s, as well as episodes of popular television series. When used in episodic TV, the phrase typically signals a turning point, a personal vow, or a confrontation with past trauma, even when the plot is not directly about historical genocide.

The phrase is also common in publishing. Several nonfiction books employ it to frame accounts of the Holocaust or to argue for vigilance against hatred and state violence. Other titles apply “Never Again” to national security, justice policy, or the interpretation of political periods after major conflicts. In addition, some authors use the wording for alternate-history or speculative series, where the title suggests an attempt to rewrite outcomes or prevent catastrophic events in imagined timelines. Across these works, the phrase functions as a warning, a lesson drawn from history, or a call to collective responsibility.

Music has likewise embraced “Never Again” as an album title, an EP name, and a recurring song title. Artists across rock, metal, pop, and electronic styles have used it to express regret, resolve, protest, or recovery. Because the phrase is short and emphatic, it lends itself to lyrics about breaking destructive cycles—whether in relationships, personal behavior, or broader social conditions.

Beyond entertainment and publishing, “Never Again” appears in the names of advocacy groups and public initiatives. Organizations and campaigns using the phrase often focus on fighting racism and antisemitism, promoting human rights, or responding to contemporary threats such as political discrimination or gun violence. Related expressions—such as “Lest We Forget,” “Never Forget,” and equivalents in other languages—are often grouped with “Never Again” because they share an emphasis on memory, accountability, and prevention.

Secret House Against the World is a full-length studio release by Canadian hip hop artist Buck 65. Issued in 2005 through WEA, the record stands out for blending rap with elements drawn from indie rock, electronic music, and left-field pop. Several guest musicians and producers contribute to its sound, including members of Tortoise, as well as Gonzales, turntablist D-Styles, and songwriter Tim Rutili. Their involvement helps give the album a wider palette than a typical boom-bap production, with arrangements that shift between sparse beats, layered instrumentation, and more melodic passages.

Others focused on Buck 65’s delivery, noting that he sounds more comfortable matching his voice to rootsy or unconventional backdrops than on earlier releases. text:
Boneland, published in 2012, is a novel by Alan Garner that continues the story begun in his earlier books set around Alderley Edge in Cheshire. The central character is Colin, once a boy in the previous tales and now an adult who keeps to himself in a small, prefabricated shelter perched in an old quarry. Although he remains close to the landscape that shaped his childhood, his life has taken a more scientific direction: he works as an academic connected with the nearby radio astronomy facilities at Jodrell Bank.

Colin’s present is defined by a striking gap in memory. He cannot recall anything from before early adolescence, which leaves large portions of his identity inaccessible, including family connections and the extraordinary events suggested by the earlier novels. To address this, he attends psychotherapy. Much of the narrative follows the slow, often uncomfortable process of recovery, showing how fragments of recollection can surface through conversation, association, and emotional pressure rather than through simple logical deduction.

Running alongside Colin’s modern story is a second thread set in deep prehistory in the same region. A solitary person living in a cave landscape sets out from a rocky chasm to seek contact and belonging. The two storylines echo each other across time, linking personal memory with the older, shared patterns of myth and place. Garner has described his interest in the motif of the “sleeping hero,” and the book also draws meaning from an ancient stone hand axe, a tool that acts as both archaeological object and symbolic bridge between eras.

The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Sorocaba is a Latin-rite ecclesiastical jurisdiction headquartered in Sorocaba, in the state of São Paulo, Brazil. It serves as a center of pastoral administration for parishes, clergy formation, and Catholic institutions in its territory, and it also leads an ecclesiastical province made up of neighboring dioceses.

The local church began on 4 July 1924, when Sorocaba was separated from surrounding jurisdictions and erected as the Diocese of Sorocaba. This reorganization reflected population growth and the need for more direct oversight of communities in the region. Decades later, on 29 April 1992, the diocese was elevated to the rank of metropolitan archdiocese, giving it additional responsibilities toward the dioceses placed under its province.

Leadership has passed through several bishops and archbishops. In the period as an archdiocese, the ordinary has been Archbishop Júlio Endi Akamine, S.A.C., in office since 28 December 2016, preceded by Archbishop Eduardo Benes de Sales Rodrigues (2005–2016) and Archbishop José Lambert Filho, C.S.S. (1992–2005). Earlier, as a diocese, it was governed by Bishop José Carlos de Aguirre (1924–1973), followed by Bishop José Melhado Campos (1973–1981) and then Bishop José Lambert Filho (1981–1992).

The archdiocese has also included coadjutor and auxiliary bishops who later received assignments elsewhere, and some priests from Sorocaba have been appointed bishops in other Brazilian dioceses. Its suffragan dioceses include Itapetininga, Itapeva, Jundiaí, and Registro.

text:
A toy soldier is a small model figure designed to resemble a military soldier. While many people think of painted plastic or metal figurines used in children’s play or in collectible displays, the phrase “toy soldier” also appears as a title or theme across a range of cultural works.

In literature, the term has been used for both poetry and fiction. It can serve as a straightforward reference to the miniature figures themselves, but it is also often employed as a metaphor for duty, conformity, or the loss of individuality. Some novels and other written works use “toy soldiers” to evoke controlled behavior or to comment on war from a domestic, everyday perspective.

Film and television have adopted the phrase in multiple ways. It has been used for action stories involving hostage situations, for dramatic narratives focused on conflict and resilience, and for documentary projects exploring real events or social issues. Individual television episodes in different series have also carried “toy soldier” as an episode title, typically to suggest characters being manipulated by larger forces or placed into rigid roles.

The name is also prominent in gaming. “Toy Soldiers” has been used for action-strategy titles that blend playful miniature aesthetics with battlefield mechanics, sometimes expanding into sequels and follow-up releases. These games often treat warfare as a tabletop-like scenario, using stylized units and accessible controls while still incorporating tactical decision-making.

In music, “Toy Soldier(s)” appears as the name of performing groups as well as the title of songs spanning pop, rock, and hip-hop. Songwriters frequently use the image to explore themes such as emotional vulnerability, being controlled by someone else, or the tension between innocence and conflict.

Related titles sometimes reference similar concepts using other terms for animated figures or miniature fighters, reinforcing the enduring appeal of the toy-soldier image in entertainment and art.

Hank Jones, Ray Brown, and drummer Jimmie Smith teamed up in 1976 to record a straight-ahead jazz trio date for Concord Jazz that later appeared under the alternate title *Rockin’ in Rhythm*. Built around familiar standards, the session highlights the group’s shared sense of time and their conversational approach to melody and accompaniment. A notable feature is Jones’s decision to alternate instruments: on several tracks he moves from acoustic piano to electric piano, changing the color of the ensemble without altering its small-group format.

Critical response to the album has been mixed but generally appreciative. Reviewers often point to the trio’s tight coordination and the clarity of Jones’s phrasing, while noting that the electric piano brings a different character to his playing. Some commentary has singled out performances such as “Bags’ Groove” and “Spring Is Here” as especially effective examples of the trio’s balance between swing, restraint, and blues feeling. Other assessments have been less enthusiastic about parts of the repertoire, suggesting that the song choices are uneven compared with other releases Jones made in the same era.

The track list includes “Your Feet’s Too Big,” “My Ship,” “Alone Together,” and the Ellington-associated “Rockin’ in Rhythm,” with Jones, Brown, and Smith comprising the full personnel.

The company specializes in large-scale machinery used in power generation, with a product range that includes steam turbines, turbine generators, and related components. Its steam turbine designs cover high-capacity units that can be applied in conventional thermal stations as well as in nuclear energy, where reliability and long service life are critical requirements. In addition to supplying domestic projects, the firm has participated in deliveries to dozens of foreign markets, and its export activity has been especially noticeable in parts of Asia.

The modern company was assembled by bringing together several long-established enterprises and design organizations in the Russian power-engineering sector. This structure reflects the way heavy electrical machinery is typically produced: different plants focus on castings and metalworking, generator manufacturing, blade production, control and testing, and engineering services. By combining these capabilities under one corporate umbrella, the company is able to develop equipment, manufacture key assemblies, and support installation and maintenance through the full life cycle of a power unit.

Changes in ownership were an important part of its early history. After the company’s creation, a controlling stake was held through an investment vehicle linked to a major Russian industrial shareholder, while a significant minority stake belonged to an international engineering group. Several years later, the foreign partner exited by selling its shares, and the company subsequently left the Russian stock exchange. A later mandatory buyout offer to remaining minority shareholders prompted public criticism from an investor advocacy organization, followed by a regulatory review and an administrative fine related to the offer process.

Power Machines’ portfolio includes different classes of turbines and turbine-generator sets, as well as gas-turbine and combined-cycle solutions developed in-house or produced under licensing arrangements. In practical terms, this means the company can supply equipment for various plant configurations, from standalone steam turbine units to modern installations that pair gas and steam turbines to improve efficiency. Dedić has also been involved with Bosnia and Herzegovina’s youth national teams, most notably at under-21 level.

The Hapa–Bilaspur Superfast Express is a long-distance passenger train in India that links Hapa in Gujarat with Bilaspur Junction in Chhattisgarh. It is operated by the Western Railway and runs once a week in each direction under train numbers 22939 and 22940.

In terms of performance, the service covers a distance of about 1,692 kilometres. The Hapa to Bilaspur journey typically takes just over 30 hours, with an average speed close to the mid-50 km/h range. The return trip from Bilaspur to Hapa is of similar duration, with minor differences due to operational factors and scheduled stops.

The train uses conventional ICF coaches designed for a maximum speed of around 110 km/h. Its rake generally includes a mix of air-conditioned and non-air-conditioned accommodation, such as AC 2-tier and AC 3-tier coaches, sleeper class coaches, and general unreserved coaches. A combined seating-and-luggage coach arrangement is also provided to handle parcels and passenger baggage.

Traction changes along the route are a notable operational feature. A diesel locomotive typically hauls the train from Hapa to Ahmedabad. Beyond Ahmedabad, an electric locomotive takes over for the remaining run to Bilaspur, with the same pattern followed in the opposite direction.

The rake is also used for other services when not assigned to this train, helping optimize coach utilization across the network.

Stampede is a black-and-white American Western released in 1949 under the direction of Lesley Selander. The film features Rod Cameron, Gale Storm, Johnny Mack Brown, and Don Castle in leading roles, with a supporting cast that includes Steve Clark, Donald Curtis, and John Miljan. Set in Arizona ranch country, the story revolves around land, water rights, and the uneasy arrival of new settlers.

The central characters are brothers Mike and Tim McCall, owners of a sizable cattle operation. To profit from unused acreage, they sell part of their range to families hoping to start farms. However, once the newcomers reach the property, they discover that the promised land lacks reliable water. The McCall ranch has blocked the local river with a dam, effectively keeping control of the area’s main supply.

John Dawson, one of the settlers, turns to the county sheriff, Aaron Ball, seeking help. The sheriff’s response is cautious and limited, reflecting the power the ranchers hold and the difficulty of enforcing a fair settlement. As tensions increase, Tim McCall grows closer to Dawson’s daughter, Connie, adding a personal conflict to the larger dispute.

With legal options failing, some settlers consider direct action, including sabotaging the dam. Retaliation threatens to escalate into violence, with plans aimed at driving the McCall herd into a destructive stampede. Like many Westerns of its era, the film uses romance and confrontation to explore authority, resources, and frontier justice.

WKLF (1260 AM) is an AM radio station that airs a soft oldies music lineup by relaying programming from its sister outlet, WBRI, based in a nearby regional hub. Licensed to the town of Fairview, New York, the station targets listeners across the Riverbend area and surrounding rural communities. The facility is operated by Northfield Media Group, which also owns several signals in the region.

### Early years on 1260 AM
The 1260 frequency first became a local voice in 1961, when it signed on as WFRV with a general-interest, middle-of-the-road sound that mixed popular music, community announcements, and regular news updates. For a period, the station’s offices were housed in a downtown hotel, a common arrangement for smaller-market broadcasters that relied on central locations and walk-in access for local advertisers.

In 1967, the station adopted the call letters WLBK, reflecting new ownership and a desire to align with a larger-market station the owners admired. Like many AM outlets at the time, 1260 AM operated with a “daytimer” authorization. That meant broadcasts were limited to daylight hours to prevent interference with distant stations that could travel farther at night due to changes in the atmosphere. Each evening the transmitter went silent and resumed the next morning.

Programming shifted with audience trends. By 1973 the station moved toward a Top 40 approach, emphasizing current hits and upbeat presentation. As FM radio gained dominance for music in the late 1970s, WLBK gradually leaned into adult contemporary, keeping a broader playlist and a calmer on-air style.

### The modern station era
Following a frequency shuffle within the local market, 1260 AM went dark in 1983 and remained off the air for several years. Service returned in 1989 as WKLF, initially launching with country music and local sports coverage. In the late 1990s the station experimented with different identities, including a period when it mirrored an FM partner carrying an adult standards format. When that FM outlet later adjusted its music strategy, WKLF continued with older-leaning programming to serve longtime AM listeners.

A technical rebuild in 2012 temporarily took the station off the air while transmission equipment and an aging tower system were replaced. The upgraded facilities improved reception in outlying parts of the county and reduced interference complaints.

In 2013, WKLF switched from music to a national sports network, reflecting industry-wide interest in live events and talk programming on AM. That run lasted several years. In 2019, the station changed direction again, ending sports to begin a full-time simulcast of WBRI’s soft oldies service, bringing familiar classics and a steady presentation back to 1260 AM.

Euseby Cleaver (1745–1819) was an Anglican churchman whose career linked England’s academic world with senior leadership in the Church of Ireland. He served first as Bishop of Ferns and Leighlin from 1789 to 1809 and later as Archbishop of Dublin from 1809 until his death, although his final years in office were affected by reports of serious illness.

Cleaver was born in Buckinghamshire into a clerical family. His father, the Reverend William Cleaver, operated a school at Twyford, and this background helped shape his early education. Cleaver attended Westminster School before entering Christ Church, Oxford. There he progressed through several degrees, beginning with a Bachelor of Arts in the late 1760s and later completing advanced theological qualifications that marked him as a well-trained candidate for higher church responsibilities.

Before his move to Ireland, he held parish appointments in England. In the 1770s he became rector at Spofforth in North Yorkshire. Later, with the support of an influential patron connected to his work as a tutor, he received additional livings in West Sussex, including Tillington and Petworth. Such appointments were common at the time and often depended on networks of education and patronage.

Cleaver’s episcopal career included a short period as Bishop of Cork and Ross, followed by his transfer to Ferns and Leighlin. Political unrest in Ireland deeply affected him: during the rebellion of 1798, his residence in Ferns was attacked, and he temporarily sought safety in Wales, within the ecclesiastical sphere of his brother, also a bishop.

He married Catherine Wynne of County Sligo, and they had several children. Through his daughter Caroline’s marriage to Admiral James William King, Cleaver became the grandfather of Catherine Pennefather, later known for evangelical work. Cleaver was also associated with sympathy toward the Irish language, an interest not universal among senior clergy of his era.

Araucaria humboldtensis, sometimes called Humboldt’s araucaria, is a conifer belonging to the Araucariaceae family. It occurs naturally only in New Caledonia, where it is considered threatened because its remaining stands are small and widely separated. Many individuals grow in isolation rather than in continuous forests, which can limit pollination and reduce the chance that seedlings establish successfully.

This species is strongly tied to ultramafic substrates, especially serpentine-derived soils that often contain elevated concentrations of metals such as nickel and magnesium. Because these metal-rich landscapes are also targeted for extraction, habitat disturbance from mining and associated road building has been an important driver of population decline. Fire, invasive plants, and erosion on exposed slopes can further hinder regeneration after disturbance.

Mature trees can reach roughly 25–35 meters tall. The trunk is typically straight, bearing tiers of evenly spaced branches that radiate outward and then angle upward toward the tips. This architecture creates a striking, layered silhouette. Like other araucarias, it is monoecious: pollen cones and seed cones form on the same tree but in different parts of the crown. Seed cones develop slowly, remaining attached for multiple seasons until the large seeds are fully mature.

Growth is generally slow, and young plants may take years to become established, particularly on thin, rocky soils. However, the species can tolerate strong winds and periodic dry spells once rooted. Because of its symmetrical form and evergreen foliage, it has also been planted in cultivation as a decorative tree in suitable climates.

Pakistan’s Parliament has maintained a dedicated body to keep the Kashmir dispute on the national agenda and to project Pakistan’s stance in external forums. Commonly referred to as the Parliamentary Special Committee on Kashmir, it is largely made up of experienced members from both houses: the National Assembly and the Senate. Beyond highlighting developments in Kashmir, the committee is also meant to coordinate positions among major political parties so that the issue is presented with continuity rather than shifting with each change of government.

During the 1990s, separate parliamentary committees were constituted at different times to pursue these aims. These panels varied in size and composition, reflecting political circumstances and parliamentary strength in each period. Leadership was typically given to a senior figure with cross-party standing, which helped the committee engage other parties and represent Parliament in public diplomacy. Over the years, notable politicians have chaired these committees, and the post has been treated as significant within Pakistan’s institutional framework.

When parliamentary activity was limited, a parallel arrangement was also used. Under President Pervez Musharraf, a National Kashmir Committee was created to sustain policy attention and public outreach. This reflected the view that Kashmir required ongoing coordination even when the legislature was not fully functioning.

In later years, a larger committee structure was formed with representation from both chambers and, at times, participation by serving ministers, indicating the overlap between parliamentary advocacy and executive policy. The chairperson has generally been accorded the rank and protocol of a federal minister. In recent times, Shehryar Khan Afridi has served as the committee’s chairman.

He became widely known after winning the 1992–1993 edition of the Vendée Globe, the solo, non-stop race around the world. This victory placed him among the leading figures of French ocean sailing during a period when the sport was rapidly professionalizing.

Beyond competition, Gautier has played a significant role in team preparation and technical support. In 1989 he created Lanic Sport Development, a structure focused on coaching, logistics, and performance work for offshore projects. Through this organization he has been involved in the development of several campaigns, including providing support to sailors such as Ellen MacArthur in the late 1990s and Isabelle Joschke decades later. His work reflects a broader trend in modern offshore racing, where shore-based expertise—weather analysis, boat optimization, and project management—has become almost as important as time spent at sea.

Gautier also explored the America’s Cup environment. Together with Bertrand Pacé, he helped lead the Aleph Challenge aimed at entering the 34th America’s Cup in 2013. Nepal’s Second Constituent Assembly was a single-chamber national body created to complete the constitution-writing process after the earlier assembly could not deliver a final document. Voters chose its members in the 2013 Constituent Assembly election, with the new body beginning work in early 2014. Its central mandate was to prepare and approve a constitution, while also acting as the country’s lawmaking forum during a politically transitional period. Once Nepal’s constitution was adopted in 2015, the same institution continued its functions as the Legislature-Parliament. Its term concluded in October 2017, shortly before a new parliamentary system took effect through subsequent elections.

At the start of the assembly’s life, procedural steps focused on setting leadership and getting lawmakers formally sworn in so regular business could begin. The first sitting was chaired by the senior-most member, a common parliamentary practice intended to provide a neutral presiding figure until permanent leadership arrangements are settled. In the opening days, hundreds of elected representatives took their oaths, marking the formal start of the assembly’s authority. Major political forces publicly committed themselves to a rapid constitutional timetable, presenting constitution-making as a national priority and a test of political cooperation. The membership was also notable for high turnover, with many representatives serving for the first time, which influenced both expectations and the pace of internal organization.

Forming a government was another immediate challenge. Nepal’s interim constitutional framework encouraged parties to seek broad agreement when selecting a prime minister and assembling a cabinet. The president played a facilitating role by urging parties to choose a head of government within a set period. Negotiations then unfolded among leading parties, with discussions focused on whether to create a consensus-based administration or proceed with a majority government if full participation proved impossible. Agreements were explored on issues such as power-sharing, timelines for local elections, and a one-year goal for constitution completion. While some parties supported a government led by the largest party, others preferred to remain outside the cabinet, arguing that opposition was necessary for oversight or that key political conditions had not been met. When all-party consensus could not be achieved, the leading parties shifted toward building a majority coalition under the relevant constitutional provisions.

The assembly’s work was structured through a committee system designed to divide specialized tasks and provide detailed scrutiny of policy and administration. Committees covered areas such as state administration, public spending oversight, legislation and legal reform, governance monitoring, environmental protection, international relations and labor, and sectoral issues like finance, agriculture, development, industry, and social welfare. Additional mechanisms, including hearings and special committees, supported appointments and oversight. Together, these structures helped the assembly function not only as a constitution-writing body but also as a working parliament during a crucial period in Nepal’s institutional transition.

William T. Harris (February 3, 1844 – November 22, 1912) was a Union Army soldier who served in the 122nd Illinois Volunteer Infantry during the American Civil War. He enlisted in the summer of 1862 and was assigned as a private to Company D, a unit raised largely from central Illinois communities. Like many volunteers, Harris spent much of his service on garrison duty and in field operations as Union forces pushed deeper into the Gulf region late in the war.

Harris is best remembered for actions recognized with the Medal of Honor. During the Battle of Fort Blakely in Alabama on April 9, 1865, he took part in the assault on Confederate defenses and was credited with seizing an enemy flag under fire. Capturing a battle flag had both symbolic and practical importance: it could weaken an opponent’s morale, disrupt command signaling, and serve as clear evidence of a position being overrun. A number of medals were issued for similar acts at Fort Blakely, reflecting the intensity of the fighting and the prominence of the objective.

After the war, Harris was discharged in mid-1865. He later settled in Kansas, where he died in 1912 and was buried in a local cemetery.

David W. Blight (born 1949) is an American historian and writer known for his work on the Civil War era, the struggle over national memory, and the history of slavery and emancipation. His scholarship has helped shape how general readers and students understand the long aftermath of the war, especially the ways Americans debated what the conflict meant and how it should be remembered.

Blight was born in Flint, Michigan, and grew up in a working-class family. He completed undergraduate study at Michigan State University, then pursued graduate training in history at the University of Wisconsin–Madison, where he earned his doctorate. After teaching appointments early in his career, he joined Yale University, where he became a professor of American history and developed courses on the Civil War and Reconstruction. In addition to classroom teaching, he has often contributed to public history through lectures, interviews, and documentary projects, aiming to connect academic research to broader civic conversations.

A central theme in Blight’s work is the idea that historical events do not end when the fighting stops; instead, societies continue to contest their meaning for generations. He is particularly associated with the study of “memory,” a field that examines how monuments, anniversaries, schoolbooks, and political speeches shape public understanding of the past. Blight has argued that reconciliation between white Northerners and white Southerners after the Civil War often came at the expense of Black rights and a frank reckoning with slavery’s legacy. This approach links political history to cultural history, showing how narratives about heroism and unity can obscure the experiences of formerly enslaved people.

Among his most widely discussed books is *Race and Reunion: The Civil War in American Memory* (2001), which traces competing postwar interpretations of the conflict and explains how certain stories became dominant in national culture. The book received major recognition, including the Bancroft Prize. Blight has also written *Frederick Douglass: Prophet of Freedom* (2018), a large-scale biography that draws on decades of research into abolitionist politics, Black intellectual life, and the changing meaning of citizenship in the nineteenth century. That biography won the Pulitzer Prize for History and was praised for presenting Douglass as both a moral critic and a strategic political actor.

Blight’s published work includes edited volumes and essay collections as well, reflecting his interest in bringing primary sources and scholarly debates to a wider audience. Across his career, he has remained focused on how the United States narrates its own past—and how those narratives influence contemporary struggles over race, rights, and national identity.

Riverside Trader was one of a small group of British cargo steamers operated by a regional shipping firm that ran regular freight routes between western England and ports in eastern Canada and the United States during the interwar years. Launched soon after the First World War, ships of this type helped rebuild commercial links by carrying mixed cargoes such as manufactured goods, timber, grain, and general stores.

The vessel was constructed in 1921 at a shipyard on the River Avon. Like many merchant ships of the period, she had a steel hull and was powered by a triple-expansion steam engine. This reliable machinery drove a single propeller and provided a modest service speed of about 10 knots, which suited scheduled cargo work rather than fast passenger traffic. The layout typically included several holds, a central engine room, and deck cranes or derricks for loading in ports without modern facilities.

In peacetime, Riverside Trader followed established Atlantic lanes and worked as part of a wider fleet that connected provincial British ports with North American markets. When the Second World War began, merchant shipping was quickly drawn into the conflict. The ship was requisitioned for wartime service, sailed under blackout conditions, and was fitted with basic defensive equipment. After sustaining minor damage during an air raid while berthed in 1941, she returned to duty following repairs.

By 1943, the Battle of the Atlantic had intensified, and slow cargo steamers increasingly traveled in escorted convoys to reduce losses. In early May that year, Riverside Trader joined an outward-bound convoy heading toward Newfoundland. During a night attack by German submarines, she was struck by a torpedo and sank in heavy seas. Several crew members were lost, while survivors were recovered by an escort vessel and later landed safely in St. John’s.

A new World Bank assessment says the Palestinian economy remains far below its productive capacity, warning that a brief improvement in employment last year has given way to renewed job losses amid continuing restrictions on movement. The report estimates overall unemployment at about 25%, more than double the level recorded before the outbreak of the uprising against Israeli occupation several years ago, with younger workers facing the most severe pressures. Joblessness among people in their late teens and early twenties is placed at roughly 37%, compared with about 14% prior to the conflict, the Bank said. During a period of reduced violence and fewer disruptions in 2003, employers added around 104,000 positions and output expanded by an estimated 6%. That rebound, however, proved fragile: in the first six months of the current year the economy shed more than 22,000 jobs, eroding earlier gains.

The report links the downturn to a rise in closures affecting crossings and travel between Palestinian towns, measures imposed by Israel that limit the movement of workers and goods and raise costs for trade and production. “The frequency and scope of closures strongly influence economic activity across the West Bank,” the Bank’s representative for the West Bank and Gaza said, arguing that unpredictable access has discouraged investment and disrupted commerce.

Nearly half of Palestinians—around 47%—are living in poverty, the report adds, leaving households highly exposed to further shocks. It notes that international assistance averaging about $950 million annually has helped soften the impact, including support for temporary employment programmes. The Bank urged the Palestinian Authority to reinvigorate institutional reforms and keep public finances under control to improve confidence among investors. The findings were released as senior US officials visited the West Bank to underline support for orderly preparations ahead of elections expected in January.

A former senior executive linked to ex-Yukos chief Mikhail Khodorkovsky has told a Moscow court that the accusations against him are unfounded, rejecting claims of fraud and tax violations as lacking any credible legal basis. Platon Lebedev, a longtime business partner of Mr Khodorkovsky, has been appearing alongside him since hearings began in June in a case focused on the disputed acquisition of a fertiliser company during Russia’s privatisation era. 

Speaking at the start of his defence, Mr Lebedev said the prosecution’s narrative was internally inconsistent and relied on a reading of corporate transactions that he said did not match the documents in the case. He said the project was intended to help pupils learn how elections work, why they matter, and how individual involvement can shape outcomes. By running campaigns and taking part in the count, he added, students would gain first-hand experience of the responsibilities and choices that come with voting.

He said mock ballots could help students understand competing priorities and the practical challenges parties face when trying to persuade voters.

Voting in schools is expected to take place in early May, close to the date widely anticipated for the next general election. Election packs sent to invited schools include ballot papers, guidance for running polling stations and materials to help pupils compare manifesto promises and key issues.

The 33-year-old sustained the injury in Leicester Tigers’ 22-19 Premiership victory over Northampton Saints on Saturday, with scans later confirming a break to the ulna in his left arm. Cole is scheduled to have surgery early this week and is expected to be sidelined for six to eight weeks, putting his international availability in doubt.

Cole said he was determined to remain involved at the club while he recovers. “It’s obviously disappointing, but it doesn’t stop you doing the work you can do,” he said. “Once the operation is done, the plan is to get back in the gym quickly and keep the fitness side ticking over.”

He added that he had sought advice from team-mate James Cronin, who missed part of last season with a similar problem. “He told me the first few days are the toughest and then you can start moving forward again,” Cole said. “Hearing that helps, because you want to keep a routine and stay connected.”

Leicester head coach Michael Cheika described the timing as “cruel” after Cole had completed his first full match since December. “Dan has been building nicely and needed the minutes,” Cheika said. “He’s in excellent shape, and the frustrating part is that this comes just as he was finding rhythm. We’ll support him through the process, but it’s a significant blow.”

A committee in the European Parliament has called for substantial changes to draft European Union legislation that would define how patents apply to inventions involving software, after lawmakers declined to endorse the latest version. Members of the Legal Affairs Committee said the European Commission should return with a revised proposal, arguing that the text failed to command broad political support and left key questions unresolved. The planned directive is aimed at clarifying whether and when innovations that rely on computer code to deliver a technical effect can qualify for patent protection across the EU, an area where national approaches and court decisions have varied.

The issue has divided industry and lawmakers for years. Critics, including some small technology firms and advocates of open-source development, warn that wider patentability could tilt the market toward large multinationals with extensive legal resources, making it harder for start-ups to innovate without fear of litigation. They also say ambiguous definitions could encourage a surge of broad claims over everyday programming techniques. Proponents, backed by parts of the manufacturing and software sectors, counter that clearer rules would protect genuine research and development, reduce uncertainty for investors and help European companies safeguard products from imitation.

The draft suffered political setbacks in the Council of the EU after Poland and other governments raised objections, prompting renewed debate in several national parliaments and intensifying lobbying from both sides. At the committee session, support for the text was limited, and lawmakers concluded that reopening the process would allow a more comprehensive discussion among member states before any final vote.

Observers frequently point to the United States, where software and certain online business methods can be patented, as a reference point in the debate. Opponents fear Europe could drift toward similarly expansive protections, while supporters insist the EU can craft a distinct, narrower standard.

Software developers who distribute programs that covertly monitor activity on personal computers may soon face significant penalties under a new California measure aimed at curbing so-called spyware. The statute, set to take effect on 1 January after being signed by Governor Arnold Schwarzenegger, seeks to reduce unauthorized tracking and limit the theft of personal information by requiring clearer consent and stronger disclosure from companies that install software on users’ machines. Security specialists have warned that spyware is expected to remain a leading irritation and risk for home PC owners, in part because such programs can embed themselves deeply within operating systems and quietly transmit data back to third parties.

At its most damaging, spyware can capture sensitive details including account credentials and payment information, and it may alter browser settings or system controls to make removal difficult. Analysts say newer variants are routinely updated to evade detection, forcing consumers to rely on a mix of anti-spyware tools and frequent security patches. A common subset, often described as ad-supported software, can log browsing habits and trigger persistent pop-up advertising, disrupting normal use and potentially exposing users to further security threats through malicious links.

While lawmakers in Washington have been considering several proposals to address the problem nationwide, California’s action positions the state as an early mover on consumer computer privacy. The law prohibits the installation of software that commandeers a computer without permission and requires businesses to inform users when an application will collect data or change settings. It also allows individuals to pursue damages of up to $1,000 per incident, alongside possible enforcement by state authorities.

The legislation follows broader efforts in California to strengthen privacy protections. Recent industry surveys have suggested that spyware remains widespread on consumer PCs, with many machines carrying multiple hidden trackers. In the absence of clear legal standards, users have increasingly turned to free and commercial anti-spyware programs to detect and remove unwanted software.

The funds hold a stake of more than 5% in Deutsche Boerse, a level that in many cases can be used to call an extraordinary shareholders’ meeting. Still, under German corporate rules, the company does not require a shareholder vote to make a takeover offer, leaving opponents focused on governance pressure rather than blocking the bid directly.

Deutsche Boerse is competing with pan-European exchange group Euronext for control of the London Stock Exchange, fueling speculation that the contest could escalate into a higher-priced bidding battle. Any rapid developments may be constrained by regulators, with the UK Office of Fair Trading expected to conclude its review of competition issues tied to the rival proposals in March.

text:
France’s financial markets authority has lodged formal complaints against conglomerate Vivendi and two senior executives over a recent convertible bond offering, alleging that investor disclosures may have been insufficient and that managers could have traded while in possession of non-public information. The Autorité des marchés financiers said it has opened proceedings involving the company, its chief executive Jean-René Fourtou and chief operating officer Jean-Bernard Lévy. A complaint was also filed concerning Deutsche Bank, which advised on the transaction and handled placement of the bonds with investors, leaving it potentially exposed to sanctions if the regulator’s claims are substantiated.

According to people familiar with the matter cited by wire services, the regulator is examining whether the prospectus failed to clearly present certain risks and strategic contingencies, and whether the executives had access to sensitive details at the time they purchased portions of the offering themselves. Investigators are reported to be focusing on whether the two men knew of expressions of interest in Vivendi’s U.S. assets from investor Marvin Davis during marketing of the bonds.

Vivendi has denied wrongdoing, saying it considers the complaints unfounded and that relevant information was already in the public domain. The company argues that any approach regarding its American holdings had been discussed openly and, in any case, was not actionable after being turned down by the board.

The AMF is also reviewing claims that management was weighing the possibility of exercising rights to acquire British Telecom’s stake in Cegetel around the same period. Vivendi said such a move was merely one option among several and that markets were aware it could be considered.

The case comes as the French regulator continues to take a hard line on disclosure standards. Vivendi has previously faced penalties from the AMF following an investigation into statements made to investors during a period of aggressive acquisitions.

text: Postcards created by artists such as Damien Hirst and Tracey Emin were among the first to be snapped up within hours of the opening of the Royal Academy of Arts’ annual Secrets fundraising sale. Buyers do not learn who made a particular work until it has been purchased, when the artist’s name can be found on the reverse. Royal College of Art spokesperson Sue Bradburn said a number of high-profile contributors remained available, including photographer Mario Testino. Each postcard is sold for a fixed price of £35. The event began at 8am on Friday and is due to finish at 6pm on Saturday. Bradburn said the day started with a long line outside the venue, though the crowd had eased later in the morning. She noted that many early purchasers appeared to have arrived with specific targets in mind, spending time carefully comparing the small-format works before choosing. The postcards have been on display for public viewing since 19 November. Contributors this year also include filmmaker Ken Loach, fashion designer Hussein Chalayan and musician Graham Coxon, alongside students and recent graduates from the Royal College of Art and other art schools. Proceeds will support the RCA Fine Art Student Award Fund, which provides bursaries and grants. The sale is in its 11th year.

text: The global installed base of personal computers is on course to climb sharply over the next several years, reaching about 1.3 billion systems by 2010, according to a new forecast from market researchers at Forrester Research. The firm said the expansion will be fueled primarily by rising demand in developing economies, with countries such as China, India and Russia accounting for more than a third of all additional machines shipped during the period. China alone is projected to add roughly 178 million PCs by 2010, the report estimated, as falling prices and broader internet access bring first-time buyers into the market. Forrester said domestic manufacturers are likely to gain the upper hand in these regions by offering lower-cost models and configurations tailored to local languages, software needs and purchasing power. The outlook arrives days after IBM, long associated with the early PC industry, agreed to sell its personal computer business to Lenovo, China’s largest computer maker, in a transaction valued at $1.75bn (£900m). The combined company is expected to rank as the world’s third-largest PC supplier. “Competitive advantage in emerging markets will increasingly come from local companies that can align design, pricing and applications with regional conditions,” said Simon Yates, a senior Forrester analyst. The study puts the current worldwide PC population at about 575 million units, while predicting more mature markets in the United States, Europe and Asia-Pacific will collectively add around 150 million PCs by 2010. India is forecast to bring in about 80 million new users, with Indonesia adding about 40 million.

text: Hayao Miyazaki’s newest animated feature, “Howl’s Moving Castle,” will roll out in about 50 markets worldwide, according to its distributor. Adapted from a fantasy novel by British writer Diana Wynne Jones, the story follows a young woman cursed by a witch and transformed into an elderly figure, prompting her to seek refuge in a wandering castle owned by the mysterious wizard Howl as she searches for a way to reverse the spell. text: Madagascar has finalized the transition from the Malagasy franc to the ariary, completing a multi-year overhaul of its monetary system. Beginning Monday, retailers, employers and government agencies must list prices, salaries and official fees exclusively in the new unit, which was quoted at about 1,890 to the US dollar in early trading. The franc has ceased to be legal tender, though the central bank said it can still be exchanged at commercial banks for several years to ease the changeover for households and businesses. Officials said the shift, launched in phases in 2003, is meant to strengthen monetary credibility after a period of sharp depreciation and to curb losses linked to fake notes that had circulated widely. A senior central bank representative described the move as a statement of national autonomy, noting that the name “ariary” revives a traditional term used for money on the island before colonial administration.

text: The European Parliament has voted down draft legislation that would have expanded the scope for patenting computer-implemented inventions, sending the proposal back to EU institutions for further review. Lawmakers supported a motion to reject the text outright, meaning the measure cannot proceed in its current form and would need to be reintroduced after new consultations if it is to return to the legislative agenda. Supporters of the plan, including several large technology firms and industry groups, argued that clearer patent rules are necessary to encourage investment in research and development and to give European companies confidence that novel software-driven products can be protected from imitation. A spokesperson for a Brussels-based trade association said innovators would be more likely to develop new tools and services if the legal framework offered predictable safeguards for intellectual property. Backers also contended that the EU approach sought to draw boundaries that would prevent the broadest kinds of claims seen elsewhere, where patents may cover certain methods of doing business as well as code-based solutions. Critics, however, warned that the proposal risked granting overly strong rights for ideas implemented in software, potentially enabling litigation-heavy strategies and making it harder for smaller developers to compete. Opponents also said the measure could create legal uncertainty for collaborative development models, including open-source projects, by increasing the likelihood of infringement disputes. The bill had faced repeated setbacks in recent months, including delays linked to objections from some national delegations and calls from parliamentary committees to revise key provisions. Under EU procedures, any future version would still require approval from both the Parliament and a qualified majority of member states before it could become law.

text:
Plans by a major Hollywood studio to depict Dominica’s indigenous Carib community as cannibals in an upcoming instalment of a blockbuster pirate franchise have drawn sharp criticism from the group’s leadership. Carib Chief Marcus Laurent said meetings with representatives of the production team indicated that the screenplay contains “repeated references to cannibalism” that, he was told, are central to the plot and unlikely to be altered. Dominica’s government has confirmed that the film-makers are scouting locations on the island and have expressed interest in shooting several sequences there, citing the island’s rainforest landscape and coastline.

The Caribs, also known as the Kalinago, have long rejected accounts that portray their ancestors as cannibals, arguing the label was used by European colonisers to justify conquest and dispossession. “We resisted invasion, and that resistance was rewritten as barbarity,” Mr Laurent said. “We cannot allow old stereotypes to be recycled for entertainment.”

Filming is expected to begin later this spring, and local casting calls have already attracted large numbers of applicants seeking work as extras, according to officials involved in the preparations. Around 3,000 Kalinago people live in Dominica, which has a population of roughly 70,000, and community representatives say they worry the portrayal could affect how indigenous people are viewed by tourists and the wider public.

Mr Laurent said he has contacted indigenous organisations in the Caribbean and beyond to support an appeal for revisions. He acknowledged, however, that opinion within the community is divided, with some residents favouring the economic boost the production could bring. The studio did not respond to requests for comment.

text: A new industry initiative is aiming to help smaller record labels place more of their catalogues on major digital platforms, as music consumption continues to shift toward online purchases. text:
Newcastle manager Graeme Souness said he never sensed his side were on the verge of a shock exit as they progressed to the Uefa Cup last 16 after a 2-1 home win over Heerenveen sealed a 4-2 aggregate success. United struck quickly, benefiting from an early own goal before Alan Shearer doubled the advantage with a crisp finish, but the visitors responded after the interval to ensure a tense closing spell. “The first-leg result put us in a strong position,” Souness said. “When you score early it can make players think it’s already settled, and their goal reminded us we still had work to do.”

Shearer’s effort kept him closing in on Jackie Milburn’s long-standing club tally of 200 goals, leaving the striker a dozen short of the landmark. Souness played down suggestions the chase might influence Shearer’s plans, with the captain having indicated he expects to retire at the end of the campaign. “Records are nice, but I don’t think they decide a career,” he said. “If he’s enjoying it and feeling fit, that matters more.”

Souness also singled out winger Laurent Robert for praise, citing his delivery and willingness to drive at defenders as key to Newcastle’s most dangerous passages. “That’s the level we need from him regularly,” the manager added.

text: French household consumption edged up 1.4% in February, offering a modest boost to hopes of steadier economic momentum, according to data released on Tuesday by the national statistics office. The agency said spending was 3.5% higher than a year earlier, with stronger purchases of home appliances and other durable goods accounting for much of the monthly gain. Consumer prices, meanwhile, slipped 0.4% from January but were 1.7% above their level a year ago, pointing to easing short-term inflation pressures even as annual price growth remained firm. Not all sectors shared in the improvement: registrations of new cars declined 2.5% on the month after a small drop in January, though the market still posted a 6.1% increase compared with February last year. Economists said resilient household demand has been one of the main pillars of recent activity, but cautioned that the outlook remains exposed to external shocks. “Consumption can keep the economy afloat, but the pace is vulnerable to higher borrowing costs and renewed swings in energy prices,” said a Paris-based analyst. In neighboring Italy, a separate survey showed consumer sentiment rising to 104.1 from 103.0, its best reading since late autumn, despite softer expectations for the near term.

text: A survey of secondary school pupils has found widespread gaps in political awareness among teenagers, with many saying they do not see learning about parties and elections as a priority. In interviews conducted with 120 students aged 14 to 16 for an education report, fewer than one in three correctly identified which party currently leads the government and which forms the main opposition, while a similar proportion were unsure where the third-largest party sits. Most respondents could name the prime minister, but recognition of other senior figures was markedly lower, with fewer than two in 10 able to identify the opposition leader and only around one in 10 recognising the leader of a smaller national party. Several pupils also held mistaken views about which party is in office. The research also explored national identity, finding that the Union flag, traditional meals and familiar sporting events were the most commonly cited markers of Britishness. Many students described themselves primarily by their home nation, and references to a European identity were rare.

text: The competitive careers of Greek sprinters Kostas Kenteris and Katerina Thanou appear finished, according to the head of the national body that recently dropped domestic disciplinary findings over their alleged failure to attend a doping control. Addressing lawmakers in Athens, Greek Athletics Federation president Vassilli Sevastis said he does not expect either athlete to return to top-level racing, arguing that reputational harm has already undermined their prospects for sponsorship and participation. International officials are now weighing how to respond to the federation’s decision, while the two athletes also face proceedings in Greece’s criminal courts. Prosecutors have filed separate allegations linked to the missed test and claims that a reported motorcycle incident was staged to explain their absence. He said the panel was asked to deliver a decisive outcome without being given documentation strong enough to support sanctions. text:
The first U.S. guilty pleas tied to large-scale copyright violations on a peer-to-peer file-sharing system have been entered, federal prosecutors said. Authorities identified the defendants as William Trowbridge of New York and Michael Chicoine of Texas, who admitted to participating in an online scheme that distributed copyrighted music, films and software without permission. The men face potential sentences of up to five years in prison and fines that can reach $250,000, according to the Department of Justice.

In court filings and a statement, prosecutors said the two helped run key “hub” servers used to coordinate a wider sharing community operating on the Direct Connect network, a platform that enables users to exchange files by connecting through centralized directories. Investigators allege the group, described by officials as an organized piracy ring, required members to make substantial collections available to others—ranging from small libraries to massive archives measured in gigabytes—in order to gain access.

Federal agents said they were able to obtain numerous copyrighted works directly from the network as part of the investigation, including feature films, commercial software, video games and music tracks, which officials characterized as evidence of a deliberate operation rather than casual sharing. The case grew out of a series of enforcement actions carried out in August, when the FBI executed search warrants at multiple locations linked to suspected online piracy activity.

The raids were part of an initiative known as Operation Digital Gridlock, aimed at dismantling networks accused of trafficking in pirated digital content. Prosecutors said both men pleaded guilty to conspiracy to commit felony copyright infringement, and also acknowledged conduct intended to provide commercial benefit. Sentencing is scheduled for 29 April.

text:
Climate change risks accelerating beyond manageable limits within the next few decades, Scotland’s environmental regulator has told MSPs as part of a parliamentary inquiry into the country’s readiness for a warmer, more volatile climate. Giving evidence to Holyrood’s environment committee, officials from the Scottish Environment Protection Agency said emissions from transport and energy continue to rise, and warned that existing policies may not cut greenhouse gases quickly enough. Witnesses argued that Scotland will likely need a mix of measures, including rapid expansion of renewable generation and continued use of low‑carbon baseload power, while broader efforts to curb demand are scaled up. 

Several contributors to the session said large onshore wind developments could become more common, bringing visible changes to rural landscapes, while investment in grid upgrades and storage would be required to maintain reliability. Others urged ministers to focus on reducing aviation within the UK and shifting more journeys onto electrified rail services, alongside cleaner buses and support for active travel. 

The committee also heard fresh analysis from marine researchers monitoring the Atlantic approaches to Scotland, who reported signs that severe weather could become more frequent and more damaging. Scientists involved in a multi‑institution study have been examining wave patterns and storm surges using satellite observations and buoy data collected over recent years, with a focus on the waters off the west coast and around the Hebrides. text: Second seed Joachim Johansson claimed the Australian Hardcourt Championships in Adelaide on Sunday, defeating American Taylor Dent 7-5 6-3 to secure the second title of his professional career. text:
The Manhattan recording complex where John Lennon worked on some of his last sessions is set to shut its doors in the coming weeks, marking the end of an era for one of New York’s best-known studios. The Hit Factory, a fixture of the city’s music scene for decades, built its reputation by hosting major acts across pop, rock and hip-hop, but operators say changing technology and shifting client demand have made the large facility increasingly difficult to sustain. The company plans to move operations to a smaller location in Miami, reflecting an industry-wide drift toward compact rooms and home-based production.

Lennon is among the studio’s most closely associated artists, having recorded material there for his comeback album “Double Fantasy” in the late 1970s. Founded in 1968 by songwriter and producer Jerry Ragovoy, the business later changed hands and expanded under producer Edward Germano into a multi-room complex offering recording, mixing and mastering services under one roof. Early sessions included work by Stevie Wonder, and the studio’s credits grew to encompass landmark projects such as Bruce Springsteen’s “Born in the U.S.A.,” the Rolling Stones’ “Emotional Rescue,” and Paul Simon’s “Graceland.” Over the years, artists ranging from Madonna and David Bowie to Jay-Z and Beyoncé booked time at the facility.
