text:
I’ll admit I went into this movie with a raised eyebrow. The idea of Danny DeVito being cast as a high-powered Wall Street predator sounds like a stunt on paper, and the romantic angle with Penelope Ann Miller is a stretch the film doesn’t fully justify. There’s also a missing layer: you can sense there’s history between certain characters that never quite gets unpacked.

That said, once it gets moving, it’s surprisingly fun and confident. DeVito doesn’t try to play the role “big”; he leans into his own presence and ends up feeling completely credible as a ruthless dealmaker with street instincts. By the middle, I wasn’t questioning it anymore—I was buying the whole persona.

The supporting cast helps a lot. Dean Jones brings a weary, pragmatic energy that grounds the corporate scheming, and Gregory Peck delivers the kind of steady, authoritative performance you expect from him. Flaws aside, it’s an entertaining watch.

text:
This isn’t the kind of film you’d automatically associate with Kitano if you only know him for sudden brutality or tough-guy cool. That contrast is exactly why it works. Here he steps back from the spotlight and lets the mood do the heavy lifting. The rhythm is deliberately unhurried, with long stretches where very little “happens” in the conventional sense, yet it never feels empty. It’s more like watching someone think.

The story follows a man trying to keep his everyday obligations from crushing what he actually cares about—work, art, and the complicated gravity of romance pulling in different directions. It quietly asks whether ambition is a gift or a trap, and whether hope survives routine.

If you’re patient with slow cinema, the payoff is subtle but lingering.

text:
I picked this up as part of a multi-disc compilation of classic Jolly Frolics cartoons, and it ended up being one of the more memorable entries. A quick heads-up: there are light plot details below. This installment in the Ham and Hattie run is essentially two bite-sized cartoons stitched together with music, which makes it feel like a mini program rather than a single short.

The first segment follows Hattie as she fusses over a little sailboat in a fountain. It’s simple, charming, and driven more by rhythm and visuals than dialogue, with a small mishap that’s resolved thanks to a helpful authority figure.

The second piece shifts gears to a small-town ensemble that’s treated like background noise—until an important guest is on the way and suddenly everyone needs a band. The turnaround is funny and a bit pointed. Overall, the set is a great purchase, and this pairing is an easy recommendation.

text:
Scary Movie feels like it’s making fun of the exact thing that drives me crazy in most slashers: characters surviving only because they keep choosing the worst possible option. The opening bit nails that point immediately—our “victim” has chances to grab something useful, and instead goes for the most ridiculous item imaginable. It’s not scary, but it’s a perfect jab at how horror scripts force people to act brain-dead just to keep the plot moving.

What surprised me is how committed the cast is. The Wayans, Anna Faris, and the rest lean into the overacting and cheesy line delivery like they’re channeling every forgettable teen thriller from the 90s. If you’ve just sat through a serious horror movie that annoyed you, this is a great palate cleanser.
